comments.body: If you read the previous test, all it was checking that a dry run printed the right name.  It never checked the actual content and the file parsing is just re-testing the resource builder which already has unit tests.
Like the majority of unit tests in kubectl :sob:
for objects which exist in multiple versions, we should ensure the various versions work properly

```
	switch t := obj.(type) {
	case *v1.Service:
		t.Spec.Selector, err = copyOldSelector()
	default:
		err = fmt.Errorf("setting a selector is only supported for Services")
	}
```
`set selector` now just support `v1.service`.  `extensionsv1beta1.Deployment` test for failed cases.
Why don't we want an error in this case?

If return an error here,  We can not output an exact error to make a difference between `kubectl set selector` and `kubectl set selector -f test.yaml`.  We would output the error when run Validate(). For example.
```
#./cluster/kubectl.sh set selector       
error: one or more resources must be specified as <resource> <name> or <resource>/<name>

#./cluster/kubectl.sh set selector -f test.yaml
error: one selector is required
```
Ah yes, I see this is testing the TestGetResourcesAndSelector method.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +288,292 @@			args:          args{args: []string{}},
			wantResources: []string{},
			wantErr:       false,
			wantSelector:  nil,
		},
